    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ description: Learn how to improve your security posture with Microsoft Entra.\n ms.service: entra\n ms.subservice: fundamentals\n ms.topic: reference\n-ms.date: 08/21/2025\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n@@ -14,14 +14,7 @@ ms.reviewer: ramical\n ---\n # Configure Microsoft Entra for increased security (Preview)\n \n-The security recommendations in this document are designed to help you improve your security posture in Microsoft Entra. These recommendations are influenced by accepted industry standards like those developed by NIST, the configuration baselines we use internally at Microsoft, and our experiences with customers. The recommendations are organized by the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars) pillars:\n-\n-- Protect identities and secrets\n-- Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n-- Protect networks\n-- Protect engineering systems\n-- Monitor and detect cyberthreats\n-- Accelerate response and remediation\n+In Microsoft Entra, we group our security recommendations into several main areas. This structure allows organizations to logically break up projects into related consumable chunks.\n \n > [!TIP]\n > Some organizations might take these recommendations exactly as written, while others might choose to make modifications based on their own business needs. In our initial release of this guidance, we focus on traditional [workforce tenants](/entra/external-id/tenant-configurations#workforce-tenants). These workforce tenants are for your employees, internal business apps, and other organizational resources. \n@@ -30,237 +23,88 @@ We recommend that all of the following controls be implemented where     "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,52 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance - Monitor and detect cyberthreats\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to monitor and detect threats.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+\n+# Configure Microsoft Entra for Zero Trust: Monitor and detect cyberthreats\n+\n+Having robust health monitoring and threat detection capabilities is one of the six pillars of the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars). These guidelines are designed to help you set up a comprehensive logging system for archival and analysis. We include recommendations related to the triage of risky sign-ins, risky users, and authentication methods.\n+\n+The first step to aligning with this pillar is to configure diagnostic settings for all Microsoft Entra logs so all changes made in your tenant are stored and accessible for analysis. Other recommendations in this pillar focus on the timely triage of risk alerts and Microsoft Entra recommendations. The key takeaway is to know what logs, reports, and health monitoring tools are available and to monitor them regularly.\n+\n+## Security guidance\n+\n+### Diagnostic settings are configured for all Microsoft Entra logs\n+[!INCLUDE [21860](../includes/secure-recommendations/21860.md)]\n+\n+### Privileged role activations have monitoring and alerting configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21818](../includes/secure-recommendations/21818.md)]\n+\n+### Privileged users sign in with phishing-resistant methods\n+[!INCLUDE [21781](../includes/secure-recommendations/21781.md)]\n+\n+### All high-risk users are triaged\n+[!INCLUDE [21861](../includes/secure-recommendations/21861.md)]\n+\n+### All high-risk sign-ins are triaged\n+[!INCLUDE [21863](../includes/secure-recommendations/21863.md)]\n+\n+### All user sign-in activity uses strong authentication methods\n+[!INCLUDE [21800](../includes/secure-recommendations/21800.md)]\n+\n+### High priority Microsoft Entra recommendations are addressed\n+[!INCLUDE [22124](../includes/secure-recommendations/22124.md)]\n+\n+### ID Protection notifications enabled\n+[!INCLUDE [21798](../includes/secure-recommendations/21798.md)]\n+\n+### No legacy authentication sign-in activity\n+[!INCLUDE [21795](../includes/secure-recommendations/21795.md)]\n+\n+### All Microsoft Entra recommendations are addressed\n+[!INCLUDE [21866](../includes/secure-recommendations/21866.md)]"
  },

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-engineering-systems.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-engineering-systems.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-engineering-systems.md?ref=5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,60 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance - Protect engineering systems\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to protect engineering systems.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+# Configure Microsoft Entra for Zero Trust: Protect engineering systems\n+\n+The [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars) pillar for protecting engineering systems was first developed to safeguard Microsoft’s own software assets and infrastructure. The practices and insights gained from this internal work are now shared with customers, enabling you to strengthen your own environments.\n+\n+These recommendations focus on ensuring least privilege access to your organization's engineering systems and resources. \n+\n+## Security recommendations\n+\n+### Emergency access accounts are configured appropriately\n+[!INCLUDE [21835](../includes/secure-recommendations/21835.md)]\n+\n+### Global Administrator role activation triggers an approval workflow\n+[!INCLUDE [21817](../includes/secure-recommendations/21817.md)]\n+\n+### Global Administrators don't have standing access to Azure subscriptions\n+[!INCLUDE [21788](../includes/secure-recommendations/21788.md)]\n+\n+### Creating new applications and service principals is restricted to privileged users\n+[!INCLUDE [21807](../includes/secure-recommendations/21807.md)]\n+\n+### Inactive applications don't have highly privileged Microsoft Graph API permissions\n+[!INCLUDE [21770](../includes/secure-recommendations/21770.md)]\n+\n+### Inactive applications don't have highly privileged built-in roles\n+[!INCLUDE [21771](../includes/secure-recommendations/21771.md)]\n+\n+### App registrations use safe redirect URIs\n+[!INCLUDE [21885](../includes/secure-recommendations/21885.md)]\n+\n+### Service principals use safe redirect URIs\n+[!INCLUDE [23183](../includes/secure-recommendations/23183.md)]\n+\n+### App registrations must not have dangling or abandoned domain redirect URIs\n+[!INCLUDE [21888](../includes/secure-recommendations/21888.md)]\n+\n+### Resource-specific consent to application is restricted\n+[!INCLUDE [21810](../includes/secure-recommendations/21810.md)]\n+\n+### Workload Identities are not assigned privileged roles\n+[!INCLUDE [21836](../includes/secure-recommendations/21836.md)]\n+\n+### Enterprise applications must require explicit assignment or scoped provisioning\n+[!INCLUDE [21869](../includes/secure-recommendations/21869.md)]\n+\n+### Conditional Access policies for Privileged Access Workstations are configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21830](../includes/secure-recommendations/21830.md)]\n\\ No newline at end of file"
  },

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-identities.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-identities.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-identities.md?ref=5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,98 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance - Protect identities and secrets\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to protect identities and secrets.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+\n+# Configure Microsoft Entra for Zero Trust: Protect identities and secrets\n+\n+User and application authentication and authorization are the entry point into your identity and secrets infrastructure. Protecting all identities and secrets is a foundational step in your Zero Trust journey and a pillar of the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars). \n+\n+The recommendations and Zero Trust checks that are part of this pillar help reduce the risk of unauthorized access. Protecting identities and secrets represents the core of Zero Trust within Microsoft Entra. Themes include proper use of secrets and certificates, appropriate limits on privileged accounts, and modern passwordless authentication methods.\n+\n+\n+## Zero Trust security recommendations\n+\n+### Applications don't have client secrets configured \n+[!INCLUDE [21772](../includes/secure-recommendations/21772.md)]\n+\n+### Applications don't have certificates with expiration longer than 180 days \n+[!INCLUDE [21773](../includes/secure-recommendations/21773.md)]\n+\n+### Application Certificates need to be rotated on a regular basis\n+[!INCLUDE [21992](../includes/secure-recommendations/21992.md)]\n+\n+### Microsoft services applications don't have credentials configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21774](../includes/secure-recommendations/21774.md)]\n+\n+### User consent settings are restricted\n+[!INCLUDE [21776](../includes/secure-recommendations/21776.md)]\n+\n+### Admin consent workflow is enabled\n+[!INCLUDE [21809](../includes/secure-recommendations/21809.md)]\n+\n+### Privileged accounts are cloud native identities\n+[!INCLUDE [21814](../includes/secure-recommendations/21814.md)]\n+\n+### All privileged role assignments are activated just in time and not permanently active\n+[!INCLUDE [21815](../includes/secure-recommendations/21815.md)]\n+\n+### Privileged accounts have phishing-resistant methods registered\n+[!INCLUDE [21782](../includes/secure-recommendations/21782.md)]\n+\n+### Privileged Microsoft Entra built-in roles are targeted with Conditional Access policies to enforce phishing-resistant methods\n+[!INCLUDE [21783](../includes/secure-recommendations/21783.md)]\n+\n+### Require password reset notifications for administrator roles\n+[!INCLUDE [21891](../includes/secure-recommendations/21891.md)]\n+\n+### Block legacy authentication\n+[!INCLUDE [21796](../includes/secure-recommendations/21796.md)]\n+\n+### Migrate from legacy MFA and SSPR policies\n+[!INCLUDE [21803](../includes/secure-recommendations/21803.md)]\n+\n+### SMS and Voice Call authentication methods are disabled\n+[!INCLUDE [21804](../includes/secure-recommendations/21804.md)]\n+\n+### Turn off Seamless SSO if there is no usage\n+[!INCLUDE [21985](../includes/secure-recommendations/21985.md)]\n+\n+### Secure the MFA registration (My Security Info) page\n+[!INCLUDE [21806](../includes/secure-recommendations/21806.md)]\n+\n+### Use cloud authentication\n+[!INCLUDE [21829](../includes/secure-recommendations/21829.md)]\n+\n+### Users have strong authentication methods configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21801](../includes/secure-recommendations/21801.md)]\n+\n+### User sign-in activity uses token protection\n+[!INCLUDE [21786](../includes/secure-recommendations/21786.md)]\n+\n+### Restrict device code flow\n+[!INCLUDE [21808](../includes/secure-recommendations/21808.md)]\n+\n+### Authentication transfer is blocked\n+[!INCLUDE [21828](../includes/secure-recommendations/21828.md)]\n+\n+### Authenticator app shows sign-in context\n+[!INCLUDE [21802](../includes/secure-recommendations/21802.md)]\n+\n+### Password expiration is disabled\n+[!INCLUDE [21811](../includes/secure-recommendations/21811.md)]\n+\n+### Require multifactor authentication for device join and device registration using user action\n+[!INCLUDE [21872](../includes/secure-recommendations/21872.md)]\n+\n+### Enable Microsoft Entra ID security defaults\n+[!INCLUDE [21871](../includes/secure-recommendations/21871.md)]\n\\ No newline at end of file"
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-networks.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-networks.md?ref=5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,26 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance - Protect networks\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to protect networks.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+\n+# Configure Microsoft Entra for Zero Trust: Protect networks\n+\n+The \"Protect networks\" pillar of the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars) emphasizes the critical importance of securing network access and implementing network-based controls to prevent unauthorized access to organizational resources. The best practices in this pillar focus on actions such as establishing network boundaries, controlling traffic flows, and implementing location-based access policies that verify the trustworthiness of network connections before granting access.\n+\n+## Zero Trust security recommendations\n+\n+### Named locations are configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21865](../includes/secure-recommendations/21865.md)]\n+\n+### Tenant restrictions v2 policy is configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21793](../includes/secure-recommendations/21793.md)]\n\\ No newline at end of file"

    "status": "added",
    "additions": 60,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 60,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-tenants.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-tenants.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-protect-tenants.md?ref=5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,60 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance - Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to protect tenants and isolate production systems.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+# Configure Microsoft Entra for Zero Trust: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+\n+Protecting your tenant and isolating production systems is about setting tenant boundaries and keeping your production systems isolated from test and pre-production environments. Lateral movement was a critical concern from the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars). \n+\n+Even smaller organizations can protect their environments by implementing stricter guest access policies and limiting who can create tenants. Larger organizations that manage several environments should take action to prevent unauthorized tenant sprawl and lateral movement. All organizations can benefit from these checks to reduce attack surface area through unmanaged tenants.\n+\n+## Zero Trust security recommendations\n+\n+### Permissions to create new tenants are limited to the Tenant Creator role\n+[!INCLUDE [21787](../includes/secure-recommendations/21787.md)]\n+\n+### Allow/Deny lists of domains to restrict external collaboration are configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21874](../includes/secure-recommendations/21874.md)]\n+\n+### Guests are not assigned high privileged directory roles\n+[!INCLUDE [22128](../includes/secure-recommendations/22128.md)]\n+\n+### Guests can't invite other guests\n+[!INCLUDE [21791](../includes/secure-recommendations/21791.md)]\n+\n+### Guests have restricted access to directory objects\n+[!INCLUDE [21792](../includes/secure-recommendations/21792.md)]\n+\n+### App instance property lock is configured for all multitenant applications\n+[!INCLUDE [21777](../includes/secure-recommendations/21777.md)]\n+\n+### Guests don't have long lived sign-in sessions\n+[!INCLUDE [21824](../includes/secure-recommendations/21824.md)]\n+\n+### Guest access is protected by strong authentication methods\n+[!INCLUDE [21851](../includes/secure-recommendations/21851.md)]\n+\n+### Guest self-service sign-up via user flow is disabled\n+[!INCLUDE [21823](../includes/secure-recommendations/21823.md)]\n+\n+### Outbound cross-tenant access settings are configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21790](../includes/secure-recommendations/21790.md)]\n+\n+### Guests don't own apps in the tenant\n+[!INCLUDE [21868](../includes/secure-recommendations/21868.md)]\n+\n+### All guests have a sponsor\n+[!INCLUDE [21877](../includes/secure-recommendations/21877.md)]\n+\n+### Inactive guest identities are disabled or removed from the tenant\n+[!INCLUDE [21858](../includes/secure-recommendations/21858.md)]\n\\ No newline at end of file"
  },
  {
    "sha": "537e7b7acf5ac22d00c29b5b3ba018e200493f1c",

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-response-remediation.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fzero-trust-response-remediation.md?ref=5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@\n+---\n+title: Security guidance | accelerate response and remediation\n+description: Improve your security posture with the Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment to accelerate response and remediation.\n+\n+ms.service: entra\n+ms.subservice: fundamentals\n+ms.topic: concept-article\n+ms.date: 09/12/2025\n+\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+author: shlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.reviewer: ramical\n+---\n+# Accelerate response and remediation with the Zero Trust Assessment\n+\n+The ability to rapidly detect, respond to, and remediate security threats is critical in today's evolving threat landscape. As one of the pillars of the [Secure Future Initiative](https://www.microsoft.com/trust-center/security/secure-future-initiative?msockid=2bad2df65a416adb0e5838355b3e6b95#SFI-pillars), accelerating response and remediation encourages organizations to minimize the time between threat detection and containment.\n+\n+This pillar emphasizes automated, risk-based responses that reduce manual intervention and help prevent security incidents from escalating. The following Microsoft Entra Zero Trust assessment checks ensure your organization has the necessary controls in place to quickly identify and mitigate high-risk scenarios, protecting both user identities and workload identities through proactive security policies.\n+\n+## Zero Trust security recommendations\n+\n+### Workload identities based on risk policies are configured\n+[!INCLUDE [21883](../includes/secure-recommendations/21883.md)]\n+\n+### Restrict high risk sign-ins\n+[!INCLUDE [21799](../includes/secure-recommendations/21799.md)]\n+\n+### Restrict access to high risk users\n+[!INCLUDE [21797](../includes/secure-recommendations/21797.md)]"
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/5111823f2e5ef604daebfe3559cf03338c89c121/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-session-lifetime.md",

    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ description: Learn how to use Conditional Access adaptive session lifetimes to e\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 03/03/2025\n+ms.date: 09/12/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ ms.reviewer: inbarc\n ---\n # Conditional Access adaptive session lifetime policies\n \n-Conditional Access adaptive session lifetime policies help organizations restrict authentication sessions in complex deployments. Scenarios include:\n+Conditional Access adaptive session lifetime policies let organizations restrict authentication sessions in complex deployments. Scenarios include:\n \n * Resource access from an unmanaged or shared device\n * Access to sensitive information from an external network\n@@ -23,15 +23,15 @@ Conditional Access adaptive session lifetime policies help organizations restric\n \n Conditional Access provides adaptive session lifetime policy controls, letting you create policies that target specific use cases within your organization without affecting all users.\n \n-Before diving into details on how to configure the policy, let's examine the default configuration.\n+Before exploring how to configure the policy, examine the default configuration.\n \n ## User sign-in frequency\n \n-Sign-in frequency defines the time period before a user is asked to sign in again when attempting to access a resource.\n+Sign-in frequency specifies how long a user can access a resource before being asked to sign in again.\n \n-The Microsoft Entra ID default configuration for user sign-in frequency is a rolling window of 90 days. Asking users for credentials often seems sensible, but it can backfire. Users trained to enter their credentials without thinking can unintentionally supply them to a malicious credential prompt.\n+The Microsoft Entra ID default configuration for user sign-in frequency is a rolling window of 90 days. It might seem sensible to ask users for credentials often, but this approach can backfire. Users who habitually enter credentials without thinking might unintentionally provide them to malicious prompts.\n \n-It might sound alarming to not ask a user to sign back in, but any violation of IT policy revokes the session. Some examples include (but aren't limited to) a password change, a noncompliant device, or account disable. You can also explicitly [revoke users’ sessions using Microsoft Graph PowerShell](/powershell/module/microsoft.graph.users.actions/revoke-mgusersigninsession). The Microsoft Entra ID default configuration comes down to “don’t ask users to provide their credentials if security posture of their sessions didn't change.”\n+Not asking a user to sign back in might seem alarming, but any IT policy violation revokes the session. Examples include a password change, a noncompliant device, or an account being disabled. You can also explicitly [revoke users’ sessions using Microsoft Graph PowerShell](/powershell/module/microsoft.graph.users.actions/revoke-mgusersigninsession). The Microsoft Entra ID default configuration is: **don’t ask users to provide their credentials if the security posture of their sessions hasn’t changed.**\n \n The sign-in frequency setting works with apps that implement OAuth2 or OIDC protocols according to the standards. Most Microsoft native apps, like those for Windows, Mac, and Mobile including the following web applications comply with the setting.\n \n@@ -45,17 +45,17 @@ The sign-in frequency setting works with apps that implement OAuth2 or OIDC prot\n * Dynamics CRM Online\n * Azure portal\n \n-Sign-in frequency (SIF) works with non-Microsoft SAML applications and apps that implement OAuth2 or OIDC protocols, as long as they don't drop their own cookies and are redirected back to Microsoft Entra ID for authentication on a regular basis.\n+Sign-in frequency (SIF) works with non-Microsoft SAML applications and apps that use OAuth2 or OIDC protocols, as long as they don’t drop their own cookies and regularly redirect back to Microsoft Entra ID for authentication.\n \n ### User sign-in frequency and multifactor authentication\n \n-Sign-in frequency previously applied only to the first factor authentication on devices that were Microsoft Entra joined, Microsoft Entra hybrid joined, and Microsoft Entra registered. In the following examples, assume SIF policy is set to 1 hour and the PRT is refreshed at 00:00.\n@@ -116,20 +116,20 @@ Administrators should limit the number of applications they enforce a policy req\n \n A persistent browser session lets users stay signed in after closing and reopening their browser window.\n \n-The Microsoft Entra ID default for browser session persistence lets users on personal devices choose whether to persist the session by showing a **Stay signed in?** prompt after successful authentication.     "patch": "@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ description: Learn how custom controls in Microsoft Entra Conditional Access wor\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 12/05/2024\n+ms.date: 09/12/2025\n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n@@ -13,18 +13,14 @@ ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n # Custom controls (preview)\n \n-Custom controls are a preview capability of the Microsoft Entra ID.     "patch": "@@ -1,20 +1,21 @@\n ---\n title: Resilience defaults for Microsoft Entra Conditional Access\n-description: Resilience defaults and the Microsoft Entra Backup Authentication Service\n+description: Discover how to configure resilience defaults in Microsoft Entra to ensure secure access during outages while balancing real-time policy evaluation needs.\n \n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 08/13/2024\n+ms.date: 09/12/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: \n ---\n+\n # Conditional Access: Resilience defaults\n \n-If there is an outage of the primary authentication service, the Microsoft Entra Backup Authentication Service automatically issues access tokens to applications for existing sessions. This functionality significantly increases Microsoft Entra resilience because reauthentications for existing sessions account for more than 90% of authentications to Microsoft Entra ID. The Backup Authentication Service doesn't support new sessions or authentications by guest users.\n+If the primary authentication service is unavailable, the Microsoft Entra Backup Authentication Service automatically issues access tokens to applications for existing sessions. This functionality significantly improves Microsoft Entra resilience because reauthentications for existing sessions account for more than 90% of authentications to Microsoft Entra ID. The Backup Authentication Service doesn't support new sessions or authentications by guest users.\n \n For authentications protected by Conditional Access, policies are reevaluated before access tokens are issued to determine:\n \n@@ -27,11 +28,11 @@ During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service can't evaluate all condition\n - Allow policies to be evaluated using data collected at the beginning of the user’s session.\n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n-> Resilience defaults are automatically enabled for all new and existing policies. Microsoft recommends leaving the resilience defaults enabled to mitigate the impact of an outage. Admins might disable resilience defaults for individual Conditional Access policies.\n+> Resilience defaults are automatically enabled for all new and existing policies. Microsoft recommends keeping the resilience defaults enabled to reduce the impact of an outage. Admins can disable resilience defaults for individual Conditional Access policies.\n \n-## How does it work?\n+## How does it work\n \n-During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service reissues access tokens for certain sessions:\n+During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service reissues access tokens for specific sessions:\n \n | Session description | Access granted |\n | --- | --- |\n@@ -40,9 +41,9 @@ During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service reissues access tokens for c\n | Existing session – Conditional Access policies configured and the required controls, like MFA, were previously satisfied | Yes |\n | Existing session – Conditional Access policies configured and the required controls, like MFA, weren't previously satisfied | Determined by resilience defaults |\n \n-When an existing session expires during a Microsoft Entra outage, the request for a new access token routes to the Backup Authentication Service, and all Conditional Access policies are reevaluated. If there are no Conditional Access policies or all the required controls, such as MFA, were previously satisfied at the beginning of the session, the Backup Authentication Service issues a new access token to extend the session.\n+When an existing session expires during a Microsoft Entra outage, the request for a new access token routes to the Backup Authentication Service, and all Conditional Access policies are reevaluated. If there are no Conditional Access policies, or if all the required controls, such as MFA, were satisfied at the beginning of the session, the Backup Authentication Service issues a new access token to extend the session.\n \n-If the required controls of a policy weren't previously satisfied, the policy is reevaluated to determine whether access should be granted or denied. However, not all conditions can be reevaluated in real time during an outage. These conditions include:\n+If the required controls of a policy weren't previously satisfied, the policy is reevaluated to determine whether access should be granted or denied. Not all conditions can be reevaluated in real time during an outage. These conditions include:\n \n - Group membership\n - Role membership\n@@ -55,39 +56,39 @@ When active, the Backup Authentication Service doesn't evaluate authentication m\n \n ## Resilience defaults enabled\n \n-When resilience defaults are enabled, the Backup Authentication Service uses data collected at the start of the session to evaluate if the policy applies without real-time data. By default, resilience defaults are enabled for all policies. You can disable the setting for individual policies when real-time policy evaluation is needed to access sensitive applications during an outage.\n+When resilience defaults are enabled, the Backup Authentication Service uses data collected at the start of the session to evaluate whether the policy applies without real-time data. By default, resilience defaults are enabled for all policies. You can disable the setting for individual policies when real-time policy evaluation is needed to access sensitive applications during an outage.\n \n-**Example**: A policy with resilience defaults enabled requires all users assigned a [privileged role](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md) accessing Microsoft Admin portals to do MFA. Before an outage, if a user without an administrator role accesses the Azure portal, the policy doesn't apply, and the user gets access without an MFA prompt. During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service reevaluates the policy to decide if the user needs an MFA prompt. **Because the Backup Authentication Service can't evaluate role membership in real-time, it uses data collected at the start of the user’s session to decide that the policy still doesn't apply. As a result, the user would be granted access without being prompted for MFA.**\n+**Example**: A policy with resilience defaults enabled requires all users assigned a [privileged role](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md) accessing Microsoft Admin portals to do MFA. Before an outage, if a user without an administrator role accesses the Azure portal, the policy doesn't apply, and the user gets access without an MFA prompt. During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service reevaluates the policy to decide whether the user needs an MFA prompt. **Because the Backup Authentication Service can't evaluate role membership in real-time, it uses data collected at the start of the user’s session to decide that the policy still doesn't apply. As a result, the user is granted access without being prompted for MFA.**\n \n ## Resilience defaults disabled\n \n When resilience defaults are disabled, the Backup Authentication Service doesn't use data collected at the beginning of the session to evaluate conditions. During an outage, if a policy condition can't be evaluated in real time, access is denied.\n \n-**Example**: A policy with resilience defaults disabled requires all users assigned a [privileged role](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md) accessing Microsoft Admin portals to do MFA. Before an outage, if a user who isn't assigned an administrator role accesses the Azure portal, the policy wouldn't apply, and the user would be granted access without being prompted for MFA. During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service would reevaluate the policy to determine whether the user should be prompted for MFA. **Since the Backup Authentication Service can't evaluate role membership in real time, it blocks the user from accessing the Azure portal.**\n+**Example**: A policy with resilience defaults disabled requires all users assigned a [privileged role](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md) accessing Microsoft Admin portals to complete MFA. Before an outage, if a user who isn't assigned an administrator role accesses the Azure portal, the policy doesn't apply, and the user is granted access without being prompted for MFA. During an outage, the Backup Authentication Service would reevaluate the policy to determine whether the user should be prompted for MFA. **Because the Backup Authentication Service can't evaluate role membership in real time, it blocks the user from accessing the Azure portal.**\n \n > [!WARNING]\n-> Disabling resilience defaults for a policy that applies to a group or role reduces resilience for all users in your tenant. Since group and role membership can't be evaluated in real time during an outage, even users who don't belong to the group or role in the policy assignment are denied access to the application within the scope of the policy. To avoid reducing resilience for all users not within the scope of the policy, consider applying the policy to individual users instead of groups or roles.\n+> Disabling resilience defaults for a policy that applies to a group or role reduces resilience for all users in the tenant. Because group and role membership can't be evaluated in real time during an outage, even users who don't belong to the group or role in the policy assignment are denied access to the application within the scope of the policy. To avoid reducing resilience for all users not within the scope of the policy, apply the policy to individual users instead of groups or roles.\n \n ## Testing resilience defaults\n \n-You can't conduct a dry run using the Backup Authentication Service or simulate the result of a policy with resilience defaults enabled or disabled. Microsoft Entra runs monthly exercises using the Backup Authentication Service. The sign-in logs show if the Backup Authentication Service issued the access token. In **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Sign-in Logs**, add the filter \"Token issuer type == Microsoft Entra Backup Auth\" to show the logs processed by Microsoft Entra Backup Authentication Service.\n+You can't conduct a dry run using the Backup Authentication Service or simulate the result of a policy with resilience defaults enabled or disabled. Microsoft Entra runs monthly tests using the Backup Authentication Service. The sign-in logs indicate if the Backup Authentication Service issued the access token. In **Entra ID** > **Monitoring & health** > **Sign-in Logs**, add the filter \"Token issuer type == Microsoft Entra Backup Auth\" to display the logs processed by Microsoft Entra Backup Authentication Service.\n \n ## Configuring resilience defaults\n \n-Configure Conditional Access resilience defaults from the Microsoft Entra admin center, Microsoft Graph APIs, or PowerShell.\n+Set up Conditional Access resilience defaults using the Microsoft Entra admin center, Microsoft Graph APIs, or PowerShell.\n \n ### Microsoft Entra admin center\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Conditional Access Administrator](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator).\n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Policies**.\n 1. Create a new policy or select an existing policy.\n 1. Open the session control settings.\n-1. Select **Disable resilience defaults** to disable the setting for this policy. Sign-ins in scope of the policy are blocked during a Microsoft Entra outage.\n+1. Select **Disable resilience defaults** to disable the setting for this policy. Sign-ins within the scope of the policy are blocked during a Microsoft Entra outage.\n 1. Save changes to the policy.\n \n ### Microsoft Graph APIs\n \n-You can also manage resilience defaults for your Conditional Access policies using the MS Graph API and the [Microsoft Graph Explorer](/graph/graph-explorer/graph-explorer-overview).\n+Manage resilience defaults for your Conditional Access policies using the MS Graph API and the [Microsoft Graph Explorer](/graph/graph-explorer/graph-explorer-overview).\n \n Sample request URL:\n \n@@ -108,7 +109,7 @@ Sample request body:\n \n ### PowerShell\n \n-This patch operation can be deployed using Microsoft PowerShell after installation of the Microsoft.Graph.Authentication module. To install this module, open an elevated PowerShell prompt and run\n+Deploy this patch operation using Microsoft PowerShell after installing the Microsoft.Graph.Authentication module. Install this module by opening an elevated PowerShell prompt and running\n \n ```powershell\n Install-Module Microsoft.Graph.Authentication\n@@ -122,7 +123,7 @@ Connect-MgGraph -Scopes Policy.Read.All,Policy.ReadWrite.ConditionalAccess,Appli\n \n Sign in when prompted.\n \n-Create the JSON body for the PATCH request:\n+Create a JSON body for the PATCH request:\n \n ```powershell\n $patchBody = '{\"sessionControls\": {\"disableResilienceDefaults\": true}}'\n@@ -138,8 +139,8 @@ Invoke-MgGraphRequest -Method PATCH -Uri https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/identi\n \n Microsoft recommends enabling resilience defaults. While there aren't direct security concerns, evaluate whether to let the Backup Authentication Service evaluate Conditional Access policies during an outage using data collected at the beginning of the session instead of in real time.\n \n-It's possible that a user’s role or group membership changed since the beginning of the session. With [Continuous Access Evaluation (CAE)](concept-continuous-access-evaluation.md), access tokens are valid for 24 hours but are subject to instant revocation events. The Backup Authentication Service subscribes to the same revocation events CAE. If a user’s token is revoked as part of CAE, the user can't sign in during an outage. When resilience defaults are enabled, sessions that expire during an outage are extended. Sessions are extended even if the policy is configured with a session control to enforce a sign-in frequency. For example, a policy with resilience defaults enabled might require that users reauthenticate every hour to access a SharePoint site. During an outage, the user’s session is extended even though Microsoft Entra ID might not be available to reauthenticate the user.\n+It's possible that a user’s role or group membership changed since the beginning of the session. With [Continuous Access Evaluation (CAE)](concept-continuous-access-evaluation.md), access tokens remain valid for 24 hours but are subject to instant revocation events. The Backup Authentication Service subscribes to the same revocation events CAE. If a user’s token is revoked as part of CAE, the user can't sign in during an outage. When resilience defaults are enabled, sessions that expire during an outage are extended. Sessions are extended even if the policy is configured with a session control to enforce a sign-in frequency. For example, a policy with resilience defaults enabled might require that users reauthenticate every hour to access a SharePoint site. During an outage, the user’s session is extended even though Microsoft Entra ID might not be available to reauthenticate the user.\n \n ## Next steps\n \n-- Learn more about [Continuous Access Evaluation (CAE)](concept-continuous-access-evaluation.md).\n+- Learn more about [Continuous Access Evaluation (CAE)](concept-continuous-access-evaluation.md)"

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Ftroubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Ftroubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if.md?ref=132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4",
    "patch": "@@ -1,74 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Troubleshoot Conditional Access using the What If tool\n-description: Where to find what Conditional Access policies were applied and why\n-ms.service: entra-id\n-ms.subservice: conditional-access\n-ms.topic: troubleshooting\n-ms.date: 08/13/2024\n-ms.author: joflore\n-author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n-manager: dougeby\n-ms.reviewer: calebb\n-ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n----\n-# Troubleshooting Conditional Access using the What If tool\n-\n-The [What If tool](what-if-tool.md) in Conditional Access is powerful when trying to understand why a policy was or wasn't applied to a user in a specific circumstance or if a policy would apply in a known state.\n-\n-Find the What If tool in the **Microsoft Entra admin center** > **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Policies** > **What If**.\n-\n-![Screenshot of the Conditional Access What If tool at its default state.](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-tool.png)\n-\n-## Gathering information\n-\n-The What If tool needs only a **User** or **Workload identity** to get started.\n-\n-The following additional information is optional but helps narrow the scope for specific cases:\n-\n-* Cloud apps, actions, or authentication context\n-* IP address\n-* Country/region\n-* Device platform\n-* Client apps\n-* Device state\n-* Sign-in risk\n-* User risk level\n-* Service principal risk (Preview)\n-* Filter for devices\n-\n-This information can be gathered from the user, their device, or the Microsoft Entra sign-in log.\n-\n-## Generating results\n-\n-Enter the criteria gathered in the previous section, and select **What If** to generate a list of results.\n-\n-At any point, select **Reset** to clear any criteria input and return to the default state.\n-\n-## Evaluating results\n-\n-### Policies that will apply\n-\n-This list shows which Conditional Access policies would apply given the conditions. The list includes both the grant and session controls that apply including policies in report-only mode. Examples include requiring multifactor authentication to access a specific application.\n-\n-### Policies that won't apply\n-\n-This list shows Conditional Access policies that wouldn't apply if the conditions applied. The list includes any policies and the reason why they don't apply including policies in report-only mode. Examples include users and groups that might be excluded from a policy.\n-\n-## Use case\n-\n-Many organizations create policies based on network locations, allowing trusted locations and blocking locations where access isn't allowed.\n-\n-To validate that a configuration is appropriate, an admin can use the What If tool to mimic access from a location that should be allowed and from a location that should be denied.\n-\n-[![Screenshot of the What If tool showing results with Block access.](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-results.png)](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-results.png#lightbox)\n-\n-In this instance, the user is blocked from accessing any cloud app on their trip to North Korea because Contoso blocks access from that location.\n-\n-This test can be expanded to include other data points to narrow the scope.\n-\n-## Related content\n-\n-* [What is Conditional Access report-only mode?](concept-conditional-access-report-only.md)\n-* [What is Microsoft Entra ID Protection?](~/id-protection/overview-identity-protection.md)\n-* [What is a device identity?](~/identity/devices/overview.md)\n-* [How it works: Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication](~/identity/authentication/concept-mfa-howitworks.md)"
  },
  {
    "sha": "1aa084e6a3326f74e77306adc0bab27e6225b291",

]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a comprehensive restructuring of the Microsoft Entra security documentation. The core `configure-security.md` file has been significantly revised, moving from a pillar-based approach to a more organised grouping of security recommendations. This change is accompanied by the creation of six new markdown files, each dedicated to a specific Zero Trust security pillar (Protect identities and secrets, Protect tenants and isolate production systems, Protect networks, Protect engineering systems, Monitor and detect cyberthreats, and Accelerate response and remediation), providing detailed guidance within each area. Additionally, the table of contents for the fundamentals section has been updated to reflect these changes, and a redirection has been added for the 'What If' tool documentation. Some minor updates have also been made to the Conditional Access documentation, including date changes and clarifying wording.

The access token is provided in each request made to the app and the validity of the request is checked before each request.\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> While it's not possible to setup OAuth on the non-gallery applications, you can manually generate an access token from your authorization server and input it as the secret token to a non-gallery application. This allows you to verify compatibility of your SCIM server with the Microsoft Entra provisioning service before onboarding to the app gallery, which does support the OAuth code grant. \n \n **Long-lived OAuth bearer tokens:** If your application doesn't support the OAuth authorization code grant flow, instead generate a long lived OAuth bearer token that an administrator can use to set up the provisioning integration. The token should be perpetual, or else the provisioning job is [quarantined](application-provisioning-quarantine-status.md) when the token expires.\n " }, { "sha": "981e619d09359dda7c91659357127ce34eeb4d04", "filename": "docs/identity/authentication/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 18, "deletions": 1, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md?ref=132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4", "patch": "@@ -29,7 +29,8 @@ A CRL works by providing a mechanism to check the validity of certificates used\n \n - **Certificate Issuance:** When a certificate is issued by a CA, it is valid until its expiration date unless it is revoked earlier. Each certificate contains a public key and is signed by the CA.\n - **Revocation:** If a certificate needs to be revoked (for example, if the private key is compromised or the certificate is no longer needed), the CA adds it to the CRL.\n-- **CRL Distribution:** The CA publishes the CRL to a location accessible by clients, such as a web server or a directory service. The CRL is typically signed by the CA to ensure its integrity.\n+- **CRL Distribution:** The CA publishes the CRL to a location accessible by clients, such as a web server or a directory service. The CRL is typically signed by the CA to ensure its integrity. If the CRL is not signed by the CA, a cryptography error [AADSTS2205015](./concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md#crl-error-reference) is thrown and follow the steps in [FAQ](./concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md#frequently-asked-questions) to troubleshoot the issue.\n+\n - **Client Check:** When a client presents a certificate for authentication, the system retrieves the CRL for each CA in the certificate chain from its published locations and checks for any revoked CAs. If any CRL location is unavailable, authentication fails because the system cannot verify the certificate’s revocation status.\n - **Authentication:** If the certificate is found in the CRL, the authentication attempt is rejected, and the client is denied access. If the certificate is not in the CRL, the authentication proceeds as normal.\n - **CRL Updates:** The CRL is updated periodically by the CA, and clients should ensure they have the latest version to make accurate decisions about certificate validity. The system does cache the CRL for a certain period to reduce network traffic and improve performance, but it does also check for updates regularly.\n@@ -222,6 +223,22 @@ In the CBA Authentication methods policy, select **Configure** and then select *\n \n When a problem prevents Microsoft Entra from downloading the CRL, the cause is often firewall restrictions. In most cases, you can resolve the issue by updating firewall rules to allow the required IP addresses so Microsoft Entra can successfully download the CRL. For more information, see [List of Microsoft IPAddress](/microsoft-365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges#microsoft-365-unified-domains).\n \n+### How do I find the CRL for a CA, or how do I troubleshoot the error \"AADSTS2205015: The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) failed signature validation\"?\n+\n+Download the CRL and compare the CA certificate and the CRL information to validate that the `crlDistributionPoint` value is valid for the CA you want to add. You can configure the CRL to the corresponding CA by matching the CA's issuer subject key identifier (SKI) to the authority key identifier (AKI) of the CRL (CA Issuer SKI == CRL AKI).\n+\n+The following table and figure show how to map information from the CA certificate to the attributes of the downloaded CRL.\n+\n+| CA certificate info |= |Downloaded CRL info|\n+|----|:-:|----|\n+|Subject |=|Issuer |\n+|Subject Key Identifier (SKI) |=|Authority Key Identifier (KeyID) |\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"false\" source=\"./media/how-to-certificate-based-authentication/certificate-crl-compare.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that compares CA certificate fields with CRL information.\":::\n+\n+- [Microsoft Entra CBA Certificate Revocation List](concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md)\n+\n+\n ## Next steps\n \n - ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates Microsoft Entra ID documentation. Key changes include:

*   Refining the description and license requirements for various risk detections in Microsoft Entra ID Protection.
*   Expanding the SCIM Validator section in the SCIM provisioning guide to detail validations for creating, updating, and disabling users.
*   Adding troubleshooting steps and a comparison table for Certificate Revocation List (CRL) signature validation errors in Certificate-Based Authentication (CBA).
*   Inserting cross-references to the new CRL troubleshooting article within several other CBA-related articles, including those for mobile devices, smart cards, limitations, and migration.

ai_summary.Response: This commit modifies a Markdown document detailing the setup for uniFLOW Online provisioning. The changes involve slightly rephrasing sentences to clarify that both users *and/or* groups can be provisioned, and that the scope setting applies to these users and groups. The primary goal is to enhance the clarity of the provisioning configuration instructions.

    "patch": "@@ -3,11 +3,12 @@ title: The Global Secure Access Client for Windows\n description: The Global Secure Access client secures network traffic at the end-user device. This article describes how to download and install the Windows client.\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 06/24/2025\n+ms.date: 09/10/2025\n ms.author: jayrusso\n author: HULKsmashGithub\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: lirazbarak\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n \n # Customer intent: Windows users, I want to download and install the Global Secure Access client.\n@@ -16,7 +17,7 @@ ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n The Global Secure Access client is an essential part of Global Secure Access. All other traffic goes directly to the network. The [Forwarding Profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md) you set up in the portal decide which traffic the Global Secure Access client routes to the cloud service.\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> The Global Secure Access Client is also available for macOS, Android, and iOS. To learn how to install the Global Secure Access client on these platforms, see [Global Secure Access client for macOS](how-to-install-macos-client.md), [Global Secure Access client for Android](how-to-install-android-client.md), and [Global Secure Access client for iOS](how-to-install-ios-client.md).   \n+> The Global Secure Access client is also available for macOS, Android, and iOS. To learn how to install the Global Secure Access client on these platforms, see [Global Secure Access client for macOS](how-to-install-macos-client.md), [Global Secure Access client for Android](how-to-install-android-client.md), and [Global Secure Access client for iOS](how-to-install-ios-client.md).   \n \n This article describes how to download and install the Global Secure Access client for Windows.\n \n@@ -25,12 +26,12 @@ This article describes how to download and install the Global Secure Access clie\n - A Microsoft Entra tenant onboarded to Global Secure Access.\n - A managed device joined to the onboarded tenant. The device must be either Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined. \n    - Microsoft Entra registered devices aren't supported.\n-- The Global Secure Access client needs a 64-bit version of Windows 10 or Windows 11, or an Arm64 version of Windows 11.\n+- The Global Secure Access client requires a 64-bit version of Windows 10 or Windows 11, or an Arm64 version of Windows 11.\n    - Azure Virtual Desktop single-session is supported.\n    - Azure Virtual Desktop multi-session isn't supported.\n    - Windows 365 is supported.\n - You need local admin credentials to install or upgrade the Global Secure Access client.\n-- The Global Secure Access client needs a license. If needed, you can [buy licenses or get trial licenses](https://aka.ms/azureadlicense).\n \n ## Download the client\n \n@@ -43,26 +44,123 @@ The most current version of the Global Secure Access client is available to down\n     \n ## Install the Global Secure Access client\n ### Automated installation\n-Organizations can install the Global Secure Access client silently with the `/quiet` switch, or use Mobile Device Management (MDM) solutions, such as [Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/apps/apps-win32-app-management) to deploy the client to their devices.\n+Organizations can install the Global Secure Access client silently with the `/quiet` switch, or use Mobile Device Management (MDM) solutions, such as [Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/apps/apps-win32-app-management), to deploy the client to their devices.\n \n-### Deploy Global Secure Access client with Intune\n+### Use Microsoft Intune to deploy the Global Secure Access client\n \n-In this section, you learn how to manually install the Global Secure Access client on a Windows 11 client device with Intune.\n+This section explains how to use Intune to install the Global Secure Access client on a Windows 11 client device.\n \n #### Prerequisites\n \n-- A security group with devices or users to identify where to install the Global Secure Access client\n+- A security group with devices or users to identify where to install the Global Secure Access client.\n \n #### Package the client\n \n-Convert the `.exe` file to a `.intunewin` file.\n+Package the installation script into a `.intunewin` file.\n \n-1. Download the Global Secure Access client from the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com/) > **Global Secure Access** > **Connect** > **Client download**. Select **Download client** under Windows 11.\n-1. Go to [Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool](https://github.com/Microsoft/Microsoft-Win32-Content-Prep-Tool). Select **IntuneWinAppUtil.exe**.\n+1. Save the following PowerShell script to your device. Put the PowerShell script and the Global Secure Access `.exe` installer into a folder.  \n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> The PowerShell installation script installs the Global Secure Access client, sets the `IPv4Preferred` registry key to prefer IPv4 over IPv6 traffic, and prompts for a reboot for the registry key change to take effect.\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> Select to expand the PowerShell script.\n+\n+<details>\n+  <summary>PowerShell installation script</summary>\n+\n+```powershell\n+# Define log file\n+\n+$logFile = \"$env:ProgramData\\GSAInstall\\install.log\" New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path (Split-Path $logFile) -Force | Out-Null \n+\n+function Write-Log { param ([string]$message) $timestamp = Get-Date -Format \"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss\" Add-Content -Path $logFile -Value \"$timestamp - $message\" } \n+\n+try { $ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop' Write-Log \"Starting Global Secure Access client installation.\" \n+\n+# IPv4 preferred via DisabledComponents registry value \n+$ipv4RegPath   = \"HKLM:\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Services\\Tcpip6\\Parameters\" \n+$ipv4RegName   = \"DisabledComponents\" \n+$ipv4RegValue  = 0x20   # Prefer IPv4 over IPv6 \n+$rebootRequired = $false \n+ \n+# Ensure the key exists \n+if (-not (Test-Path $ipv4RegPath)) { \n+    New-Item -Path $ipv4RegPath -Force | Out-Null \n+    Write-Log \"Created registry key: $ipv4RegPath\" \n+} \n+ \n+# Get current value if present \n+$existingValue = $null \n+$valueExists = $false \n+try { \n+    $existingValue = Get-ItemPropertyValue -Path $ipv4RegPath -Name $ipv4RegName -ErrorAction Stop \n+    $valueExists = $true \n+} catch { \n+    $valueExists = $false \n+} \n+ \n+# Determine if we must change it \n+$expected = [int]$ipv4RegValue \n+$needsChange = -not $valueExists -or ([int]$existingValue -ne $expected) \n+ \n+if ($needsChange) { \n+    if (-not $valueExists) { \n+        # Create as DWORD when missing \n+        New-ItemProperty -Path $ipv4RegPath -Name $ipv4RegName -PropertyType DWord -Value $expected -Force | Out-Null \n+        Write-Log \"IPv4Preferred value missing. Created '$ipv4RegName' with value 0x{0} (dec {1}).\" -f ([Convert]::ToString($expected,16)), $expected \n+    } else { \n+        # Update if different \n+        Set-ItemProperty -Path $ipv4RegPath -Name $ipv4RegName -Value $expected \n+        Write-Log (\"IPv4Preferred value differed. Updated '{0}' from 0x{1} (dec {2}) to 0x{3} (dec {4}).\" -f ` \n+            $ipv4RegName, ([Convert]::ToString([int]$existingValue,16)), [int]$existingValue, ([Convert]::ToString($expected,16)), $expected) \n+    } \n+    $rebootRequired = $true \n+} else { \n+    Write-Log (\"IPv4Preferred already set correctly: {0}=0x{1} (dec {2}). No change.\" -f ` \n+        $ipv4RegName, ([Convert]::ToString($expected,16)), $expected) \n+} \n+ \n+# Run installer from local path \n+$installerPath = Join-Path -Path $PSScriptRoot -ChildPath \"GlobalSecureAccessClient.exe\" \n+Write-Log \"Running installer from $installerPath\" \n+ \n+if (Test-Path $installerPath) { \n+    $installProcess = Start-Process -FilePath $installerPath -ArgumentList \"/quiet\" -Wait -PassThru \n+ \n+    if ($installProcess.ExitCode -eq 1618) { \n+        Write-Log \"Another installation is in progress. Exiting with code 1618.\" \n+        exit 1618 \n+    } elseif ($installProcess.ExitCode -ne 0) { \n+        Write-Log \"Installer exited with code $($installProcess.ExitCode).\" \n+        exit $installProcess.ExitCode \n+    } \n+ \n+    Write-Log \"Installer completed successfully.\" \n+} else { \n+    Write-Log \"Installer not found at $installerPath\" \n+    exit 1 \n+} \n+ \n+if ($rebootRequired) { \n+    Write-Log \"Reboot required due to registry value creation or update.\" \n+    exit 3010  # Soft reboot required \n+} else { \n+    Write-Log \"Installation complete. No reboot required.\" \n+    exit 0 \n+} \n+  \n+\n+} catch { Write-Log \"Fatal error: $_\" exit 1603 } \n+```\n+\n+</details>\n+\n+2. Go to the [Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool](https://github.com/Microsoft/Microsoft-Win32-Content-Prep-Tool). Delete the app with the old client version.\n \n+### Configure Global Secure Access client settings with Intune\n+\n+Admins can use [remediation scripts](/intune/intune-service/fundamentals/remediations) in Intune to enforce client-side controls, such as preventing non-admin users from disabling the client or hiding specific buttons. \n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> Set the `$gsaSettings` to the values your organization requires in both the detection and remediation scripts.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Make sure to configure these scripts to run in 64-bit PowerShell.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/run-script-64-bit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create custom script settings tab with the Run script in 64-bit PowerShell option set to yes.\":::\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> Select to expand the PowerShell scripts.\n+\n+<details>\n+  <summary>PowerShell detection script</summary>\n+\n+#### Detection script \n+\n+```powershell\n+# Check GSA registry keys \n+\n+$gsaPath = \"HKLM:\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Global Secure Access Client\" \n+\n+$gsaSettings = @{ \n+\n+\"HideSignOutButton\" = 1 \n+ \n+\"HideDisablePrivateAccessButton\" = 1 \n+ \n+\"HideDisableButton\" = 0 \n+ \n+\"RestrictNonPrivilegedUsers\" = 0 \n+\n+} \n+\n+$nonCompliant = $false \n+\n+foreach ($setting in $gsaSettings.GetEnumerator()) { \n+\n+$currentValue = (Get-ItemProperty -Path $gsaPath -Name $setting.Key -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).$($setting.Key) \n+ \n+if ($currentValue -ne $setting.Value) { \n+ \n+    Write-Output \"Non-compliant: $($setting.Key) is $currentValue, expected $($setting.Value)\" \n+ \n+    $nonCompliant = $true \n+ \n+} \n+  \n+\n+} \n+\n+if (-not $nonCompliant) { \n+\n+Write-Output \"Compliant\" \n+ \n+exit 0 \n+  \n+\n+} else { \n+\n+Write-Output \"Non-compliant\" \n+ \n+exit 1 \n+ \n+\n+} \n+```\n+\n+</details>\n+\n+<details>\n+  <summary>PowerShell remediation script</summary>\n+\n+#### Remediation script\n+\n+```powershell\n+# Ensure GSA registry keys are present \n+\n+$gsaPath = \"HKLM:\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Global Secure Access Client\" \n+\n+$gsaSettings = @{ \n+\n+\"HideSignOutButton\" = 1 \n+ \n+\"HideDisablePrivateAccessButton\" = 1 \n+ \n+\"HideDisableButton\" = 0 \n+ \n+\"RestrictNonPrivilegedUsers\" = 0 \n+  \n+\n+} \n+\n+if (-Not (Test-Path $gsaPath)) { \n+\n+New-Item -Path $gsaPath -Force | Out-Null \n+  \n+\n+} \n+\n+foreach ($setting in $gsaSettings.GetEnumerator()) { \n+\n+Set-ItemProperty -Path $gsaPath -Name $setting.Key -Value $setting.Value -Type DWord -Force | Out-Null \n+ \n+Write-Output \"Set $($setting.Key) to $($setting.Value)\" \n+  \n+\n+}\n+```\n+\n+</details>\n+\n+### Configure settings for Microsoft Entra Internet Access with Intune\n+\n+Microsoft Entra Internet Access doesn't yet support DNS over HTTPS or Quick UDP Internet Connections (QUIC) traffic. To mitigate this, disable these protocols in users' browsers. The following instructions provide guidance on how to enforce these controls using Intune.\n+\n+#### Disable QUIC in Microsoft Edge and Chrome with Intune \n+\n+To disable QUIC in Microsoft Edge and Chrome with Intune:\n+1. In the Microsoft Intune admin center, select **Devices** > **Manage devices** > **Configuration**.\n+1. On the **Policies** tab, select **+ Create** > **+ New Policy**.\n+1. In the **Create a profile** dialog:\n+   - Set the **Platform** to **Windows 10 and later**.\n+   - Set the **Profile type** to **Settings catalog**.\n+   - Select **Create**. The **Create profile** form opens.\n+1. On the **Basics** tab, give the profile a name and description.\n+1. Select **Next**.\n+1. On the **Configuration settings** tab:\n+    1. Select **+ Add settings**.\n+    1. In the **Settings picker**, search for \"QUIC\".\n+    1. From the search results:\n+        1. Select **Microsoft Edge** and select the **Allow QUIC protocol** setting.\n+        1. Next, select **Google Google Chrome** and select the **Allow QUIC protocol** setting.\n+    1. In the **Settings picker**, search for \"DNS-over-HTTPS\".\n+    1. From the search results:\n+        1. Select **Microsoft Edge** and select the **Control the mode of DNS-over-HTTPS** setting.\n+        1. Next, select **Google Google Chrome** and select the **Control the mode of DNS-over-HTTPS** setting.\n+    1. Close the **Settings picker**.\n+1. For **Google Chrome**, set both toggles to **Disabled**.\n+1. For **Microsoft Edge**, set both toggles to **Disabled**.\n+\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/edge-chrome-profile.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Configuration settings tab showing the Microsoft Edge and Chrome settings.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/edge-chrome-profile.png\":::\n+\n+1. Select **Next** twice.\n+1. On the **Assignments** tab:\n+    1. Select **Add groups**.\n+    1. Select a group of users or devices to assign the policy.\n+    1. Select **Select**.\n+1. Select **Next**.\n+1. On the **Review + create** tab, select **Create**.\n+\n+### Configure Firefox browser settings\n+\n+Admins can use [remediation scripts](/intune/intune-service/fundamentals/remediations) in Intune to disable DNS over HTTPS and QUIC protocols in Firefox browser.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Make sure to configure these scripts to run in 64-bit PowerShell.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/run-script-64-bit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create custom script settings tab with the Run script in 64-bit PowerShell option set to yes.\":::\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> Select to expand the PowerShell scripts.\n+\n+<details>\n+  <summary>PowerShell detection script</summary>\n+\n+#### Detection script \n+\n+```powershell\n+# Define the path to the Firefox policies.json file \n+\n+$destination = \"C:\\Program Files\\Mozilla Firefox\\distribution\\policies.json\" $compliant = $false \n+\n+# Check if the file exists \n+\n+if (Test-Path $destination) { try { # Read the file content $fileContent = Get-Content $destination -Raw if ($fileContent -and $fileContent.Trim().Length -gt 0) { # Parse JSON content $json = $fileContent | ConvertFrom-Json \n+\n+       # Check if Preferences exist under policies \n+        if ($json.policies -and $json.policies.Preferences) { \n+            $prefs = $json.policies.Preferences \n+ \n+            # Convert Preferences to hashtable if needed \n+            if ($prefs -isnot [hashtable]) { \n+                $temp = @{} \n+                $prefs.psobject.Properties | ForEach-Object { \n+                    $temp[$_.Name] = $_.Value \n+                } \n+                $prefs = $temp \n+            } \n+ \n+            # Initialize compliance flags \n+            $quicCompliant = $false \n+            $dohCompliant = $false \n+ \n+            # Check if QUIC is disabled and locked \n+            if ($prefs.ContainsKey(\"network.http.http3.enable\")) { \n+                $val = $prefs[\"network.http.http3.enable\"] \n+                if ($val.Value -eq $false -and $val.Status -eq \"locked\") { \n+                    $quicCompliant = $true \n+                } \n+            } \n+ \n+            # Check if DNS over HTTPS is disabled and locked \n+            if ($prefs.ContainsKey(\"network.trr.mode\")) { \n+                $val = $prefs[\"network.trr.mode\"] \n+                if ($val.Value -eq 0 -and $val.Status -eq \"locked\") { \n+                    $dohCompliant = $true \n+                } \n+            } \n+ \n+            # Set overall compliance if both settings are correct \n+            if ($quicCompliant -and $dohCompliant) { \n+                $compliant = $true \n+            } \n+        } \n+    } \n+} catch { \n+    Write-Warning \"Failed to parse policies.json: $_\" \n+} \n+  \n+\n+} \n+\n+# Output compliance result \n+\n+if ($compliant) { Write-Output \"Compliant\" Exit 0 } else { Write-Output \"Non-compliant\" Exit 1 } \n+```\n+\n+</details>   \n+\n+<details>\n+  <summary>PowerShell remediation script</summary>\n+\n+#### Remediation script\n+\n+```powershell\n+# Define paths \n+\n+$distributionDir = \"C:\\Program Files\\Mozilla Firefox\\distribution\" $destination = Join-Path $distributionDir \"policies.json\" $backup = \"$destination.bak\" \n+\n+# Initialize variable for existing JSON \n+\n+$existingJson = $null \n+\n+# Try to read and parse existing policies.json \n+\n+if (Test-Path $destination) { $fileContent = Get-Content $destination -Raw if ($fileContent -and $fileContent.Trim().Length -gt 0) { try { $existingJson = $fileContent | ConvertFrom-Json } catch { Write-Warning \"Existing policies.json is malformed. Starting fresh.\" } } } \n+\n+#Create a new JSON structure if none exists \n+\n+if (-not $existingJson) { $existingJson = [PSCustomObject]@{ policies = [PSCustomObject]@{ Preferences = @{} } } } \n+\n+# Ensure policies and Preferences nodes exist \n+\n+if (-not $existingJson.policies) { $existingJson | Add-Member -MemberType NoteProperty -Name policies -Value ([PSCustomObject]@{}) } if (-not $existingJson.policies.Preferences) { $existingJson.policies | Add-Member -MemberType NoteProperty -Name Preferences -Value @{} } \n+\n+# Convert Preferences to hashtable if needed \n+\n+if ($existingJson.policies.Preferences -isnot [hashtable]) { $prefs = @{} $existingJson.policies.Preferences.psobject.Properties | ForEach-Object { $prefs[$.Name] = $.Value } $existingJson.policies.Preferences = $prefs } \n+\n+$prefObj = $existingJson.policies.Preferences $updated = $false \n+\n+# Ensure QUIC is disabled and locked\n+\n+if (-not $prefObj.ContainsKey(\"network.http.http3.enable\") -or $prefObj[\"network.http.http3.enable\"].Value -ne $false -or $prefObj[\"network.http.http3.enable\"].Status -ne \"locked\") { \n+\n+$prefObj[\"network.http.http3.enable\"] = @{ \n+    Value = $false \n+    Status = \"locked\" \n+} \n+$updated = $true \n+  \n+\n+} \n+\n+# Ensure DNS over HTTPS is disabled and locked \n+\n+if (-not $prefObj.ContainsKey(\"network.trr.mode\") -or $prefObj[\"network.trr.mode\"].Value -ne 0 -or $prefObj[\"network.trr.mode\"].Status -ne \"locked\") { \n+\n+$prefObj[\"network.trr.mode\"] = @{ \n+    Value = 0 \n+    Status = \"locked\" \n+} \n+$updated = $true \n+} \n+\n+# If any updates were made, back up and write the new JSON \n+\n+if ($updated) { if (Test-Path $destination) { Copy-Item $destination $backup -Force } \n+\n+$jsonOut = $existingJson | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10 -Compress \n+$utf8NoBomEncoding = New-Object System.Text.UTF8Encoding($false) \n+[System.IO.File]::WriteAllText($destination, $jsonOut, $utf8NoBomEncoding) \n+} \n+```\n+\n+</details>   \n+\n ### Manual installation\n To manually install the Global Secure Access client:\n 1. If the **Disable** action is hidden, a nonprivileged user can't disable the client.   |\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/global-secure-access-registry-key-private-hide-signout.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Registry Editor with the HideSignOutButton and HideDisablePrivateAccessButton registry keys highlighted.\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-windows-client/global-secure-access-registry-key-private-hide-signout.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Registry Editor with the HideSignOutButton and HideDisablePrivateAccessButton registry keys highlighted.\":::\n \n For more information, see [Guidance for configuring IPv6 in Windows for advanced users](/troubleshoot/windows-server/networking/configure-ipv6-in-windows).\n "

    "patch": "@@ -69,18 +69,12 @@ The default view of the suggestion provides the policy details, including a high\n \n From the details panel that opens, select **Policy impact** to see a visualization of the potential impact of the policy.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/policy-impact-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the policy suggestion details with the policy impact button highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/policy-impact-button.png\":::\n-\n Adjust the filters and the display as needed. Select a point on the graph to see a sample of the data that the policy affects. For example, for a policy to require multifactor authentication (MFA), the graph shows a sample of sign-in events where the Conditional Access policy wasn't applied. For more information, see [Policy impact](concept-conditional-access-report-only.md#reviewing-results).\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/policy-impact-graph.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the policy impact graph.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/policy-impact-graph.png\":::\n-\n ### View agent's full activity\n \n To see a detailed summary of the agent's activity and how it calculated the suggestion, select **View agent's full activity**. The agent's activity assesses policy drift, or gaps in policy coverage, for users and apps. The agent also looks for policies that can be merged or consolidated.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/view-agent-activity-link.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the policy suggestion details with the view agent's full activity link highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/view-agent-activity-link.png\":::\n-\n The **Summary of agent activity** is a natural language description of the activity illustrated in the **Agent activity map**. These details can help you understand the logic behind the suggestion so you can make an informed decision about whether to apply the suggestion.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/agent-activity-detail.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the agent activity map.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/agent-activity-detail-expanded.png\":::\n@@ -92,7 +86,13 @@ If the agent suggests modifying an existing policy, select **Review policy chang\n - Policy details are provided as both a list of all the details that are changing and a JSON view of the entire policy, with the changes highlighted.\n - For policy changes that affect users or applications, you can download a JSON file of the users and applications affected by the policy change.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/review-policy-changes.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the policy details page with the review policy changes button highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/review-policy-changes.png\":::\n+### Deep analysis (Preview)\n+\n+Deep analysis performs an in-depth review of Conditional Access policies for scenarios such as blocking legacy authentication, blocking device control flow, and policies that require device or MFA controls. It evaluates the targeted users, groups, and roles to identify coverage gaps, overlapping or redundant policies, and consolidation opportunities. It also analyzes exclusions—flagging policies that exclude a large portion of users and recommending explicit exclusion of break‑glass accounts to reduce the risk of accidental lockout.\n+\n+Because the policy suggestions that come through deep analysis might have a significant impact on your environment, you can \"snooze\" the suggestion for 14 days. This feature gives you time to investigate the suggestion and make any needed changes to your policies before applying the suggestion. You can also add notes about the suggestion that can be saved for other admins to review. If you choose to snooze the suggestion, it reappears in the list after 14 days with the notes intact.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/deep-analysis-suggestion.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the suggestion created with deep analysis with the snooze and notes buttons highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-review-suggestions/deep-analysis-suggestion.png\":::\n \n ## Apply suggestions\n \n@@ -145,4 +145,4 @@ To view a policy review report:\n \n 1. Review the report and investigate the policy as needed.\n \n-1. From the policy details page, select **Mark suggestion as reviewed** or **Snooze for 14 days**. Optionally, you can add notes about what you learned and any changes you made to the related policy.\n\\ No newline at end of file\n+1. From the policy details page, select **Mark suggestion as reviewed** or **Snooze for 14 days**. Optionally, you can add notes about what you learned and any changes you made to the related policy."

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates documentation for Microsoft Entra's Global Secure Access service. Key changes include a significant overhaul of the Windows client installation guide, introducing automated deployment with Microsoft Intune, detailed PowerShell scripts for installation and configuration, and new sections on managing browser settings for Entra Internet Access. Additionally, the Transport Layer Security configuration guide has been updated with a more recent date, and the Conditional Access agent optimization documentation now includes a "Deep analysis (Preview)" feature for enhanced policy review.
